name: A Package of Fun
description:
IF YOU ARE ON MAC: Right click on the game in Finder and press Open, then if a popup appears about malicious software/an unidentified developer, press Open. If it is an unidentified developer, I don't know why, I have a proper Apple Developer account, and it was built with it. If it's malicious software, maybe that's because of Unity?

Hello! Thanks for checking out our game!

This was submitted for the Quarantine Game Jam, and I had two other people working on it with me. The game is a small package of minigames, with some boxes in it as well. Hopefully, this will be updated a few times. It could eventually be ported to iOS and Android, and definitely MacOS (including Catalina) and Linux/Unix.

Team:.

Cian Ormond  - Programmer,  Artist, and Minigame Designer (me)

Clayton Collins - Musician and Level Designer

Expected Performance:

ON MAC, you need to be running MacOS X El Captain (10.11) and the game works on Catalina (10.15). YOU NEED A 64-BIT PROCESSOR.  On lower spec machines, specifically ones that cannot run Catalina/Mojave, it will probably not run well, but it runs at around 20-30 FPS on the 3D menu screen and 40+ FPS in the platformer game on a Mid-2015 MacBook Pro running an Intel Core i7-4770HQ, Intel Iris Pro integrated graphics, and 16GB of RAM (my main Mac). On a newer 2018/2019 MacBook Pro 15 inch (Core i7-????, Intel ?????? integrated graphics, and 16GB of RAM, you can get a consistent 40 FPS in the menu and over 60FPS in the platformer. All of these numbers are by my eye.

ON WINDOWS, you need a 32-bit processor, and it should run from Windows 7 to Windows 10. I will test it on my Windows XP VM, but I cannot get expected performance as it's not on real hardware, and the VM is set up on my Mac, not my PC. I have not performed testing on lower-spec Windows machines,  but I can test it on my Surface Pro later.

ON UNIX/LINUX, you need a 64-bit processor, and that's all I know. I can only test it in VMs, so this may not be accurate. I will test later.

Everything is ours, except for the font, which was marked as 100% Free on https://dafont.com
